chapter.htmlHeader: Scenario: Dry mouth
chapter.summary: Covers the management of patients with dry mouth.
chapter.htmlStringContent: From age 16 years onwards.

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.fullItemName: Scenario: Halitosis, excessive salivation and altered taste
Topical artificial saliva and saliva stimulant products

subChapters.htmlHeader: Managing underlying cause
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Treat any of the following underlying causes of dry mouth if appropriate:
    • Adverse effect of a drug being taken. Reduce the dose or change the drug if possible.
      • However, in practice, it is often very difficult to discontinue, or substitute drugs causing dry mouth. Many of these drugs are necessary for symptom control, and salivary gland dysfunction is usually a drug-class adverse effect.
    • Dehydration. This should be reversed except in the terminal phase.
    • Anxiety. This becomes increasingly common towards the end of life and should be managed appropriately.
    • Candida infection. See Scenario: Oral candida infection.
    • Supplemental oxygen.Consider humidification of oxygen.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
This recommendation is based on published expert opinion [Davies and Finlay, 2005; Regnard, 2010].

  • Much anxiety can be eased with clear communication and treatment of symptoms. Specialist help is needed for persistent severe anxiety [Regnard, 2010].

• Try simple saliva stimulatory measures first, as these will often relieve symptoms of dry mouth (even if rehydration is not undertaken):
    • Cold unsweetened drinks, frequent sips or sprays of cold water or ice cubes/crushed ice/ice lollies.
    • Rubbing petroleum jelly (for example Vaseline®) on the lips. However, if a person is on oxygen apply a water-soluble lubricant (for example K-Y Jelly®).
    • Sugar-free chewing gum, boiled sweets, pastilles, mints.
  • If symptom relief is not adequate, consider using:
    • A topical saliva stimulant.
    • A topical artificial saliva substitute.
    • Pilocarpine tablets. Some experts may recommend the use of bethanechol tablets as an alternative to pilocarpine tablets. However, bethanechol is not licensed for this indication.
    • For more information on topical saliva stimulants and substitutes see Topical artificial saliva and saliva stimulant products.
  • Avoid the use of acidic foods (for example pineapple) or acidic artificial saliva products (for example Glandosane®aerosol spray) in people with their own teeth.
  • Note: patient preference is likely to influence product acceptability and compliance.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Additional information
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Products can hasten tooth decay in a dry mouth if they contain sugar (for example fruit juices) or are acidic (for example topical artificial saliva or saliva stimulant products Glandsone® spray, Salivix® pastilles, and SST® tablets) [WeMeReC, 2006; Regnard, 2010; Davies and Hall, 2011]. Alternative products may be appropriate in people who still have their own teeth and are not in the terminal phase of life.
  • Avoid using glycerin, which dehydrates the mucosa further, and lemon juice, which rapidly exhausts salivary secretion; the combination acts to dry the mouth [Krishnasamy, 1995]; [Regnard, 2010].
  • Topical artificial saliva and saliva stimulant products are not licensed medicines, as they do not contain active drug ingredients. Therefore, manufacturers are not bound by the same requirements to produce trial evidence, statutory monitoring, or good manufacturing requirements as for licensed medicines. Of the products available in the UK:
    • Salinum® and SST® Saliva Stimulating Tablets are classified as appliances.
    • The remaining seven products have been classified as borderline substances by the Advisory Committee on Borderline Substances (ACBS). This means that they can be prescribed as drugs for the treatment of dry mouth caused by having (or having had) radiotherapy (or sicca syndrome), but the prescriber must endorse prescriptions 'ACBS'.
  • Note: some products contain mucin from pigs (for example AS Saliva Orthana®) which may be unacceptable to certain groups of people, such as vegetarians, and people of Jewish or Muslim faith.

These recommendations are based on palliative care textbooks and local guidelines written by experts on the basis of experience of clinical practice [NHS Scotland, 2016; WeMeReC, 2006; Davies, 2015; Regnard, 2010].

  • A Cochrane review [Furness et al, 2011] found:
    • Limited evidence that pilocarpine is effective in increasing saliva production and that sugar free lozenges and chewing gum are effective to some degree.
    • No strong evidence that any topical therapy is effective for relieving the symptoms of a dry mouth.
  • A further Cochrane review [Davies and Shorthose, 2015] found limited evidence to support the use of pilocarpine hydrochloride in the treatment of radiation-induced salivary gland dysfunction. Although pilocarpine provides a beneficial response in most people (depending on the cause of the dry mouth), adverse effects are commonly reported.

subChapters.fullItemName: When to refer or seek specialist advice
subChapters.htmlHeader: When to refer or seek specialist advice
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Refer or seek specialist advice if in doubt about the diagnosis or management of any oral problem.
  • Refer if any of the following are present:
    • Oral problems that are causing a decrease in oral intake or concerns about nutrition.
    • Severe oral herpes simplex infection as intravenous administration of aciclovir may be needed.
    • Severe mucositis. It can be extremely painful and may limit future chemotherapy or radiotherapy.
    • Suspected neutropenic ulcers and neutropenia. Seek urgent medical advice.
    • Severe or persistent candida infection.
    • Oral ulcers that are bleeding.
    • Taste disturbance that is likely to be prolonged. Refer to a dietitian where appropriate.
    • Pain that is difficult to manage.
    • Communication problems. Refer to a speech and language therapist where appropriate.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: These recommendations are based on standard clinical practice.
